text: I know some of you here put a lot of importance in performance when it comes to simulating/backtesting etc. I don't use flumine/BFLW, but from what I read people mostly use S3 storage, decompress raw JSON stream  files and run backtests like that (please correct if wrong). Given performance considerations, I was wondering if anyone uses or has given thought to utilising an alternative file format to give processing an extra zip? I'm working on some GPS stuff at the moment and it's occurring to me that a large proportion of processing time is down to JSON parsing every time I run analysis. I was wondering if anyone has tried binary file formats or something similar? Not sure if I will eventually do this as it may be a premature optimisation but I've worked a lot with binary data files which has made me start thinking about going down this route.

elements.text: I know some of you here put a lot of importance in performance when it comes to simulating/backtesting etc. I don't use flumine/BFLW, but from what I read people mostly use S3 storage, decompress raw JSON stream  files and run backtests like that (please correct if wrong). Given performance considerations, I was wondering if anyone uses or has given thought to utilising an alternative file format to give processing an extra zip? I was wondering if anyone has tried binary file formats or something similar? Not sure if I will eventually do this as it may be a premature optimisation but I've worked a lot with binary data files which has made me start thinking about going down this route.

text:
Don't know if you're aware that there's a binary json format BSON: <https://bsonspec.org/>

I've never used it, but might be worth looking in to.

text: yeah sorry :slightly_smiling_face: been there, done that, never again. A binary format is composed by a bunch of things: (1) a reader, (2) a writer (3) a compression method (4) a schema

elements.text: yeah sorry
been there, done that, never again. A binary format is composed by a bunch of things: (1) a reader, (2) a writer (3) a compression method (4) a schema

text: now the main time you spend with JSON is decompression + schema decoding and allocating all the stuff for the dictionary that JSON produces.

elements.text: now the main time you spend with JSON is decompression + schema decoding and allocating all the stuff for the dictionary that JSON produces.

text: Well yes. Probably should have specified I don't use Python - does  it not play nicely with binary format file data?

elements.text: Well yes. Probably should have specified I don't use Python - does  it not play nicely with binary format file data?

text: JSON becomes recursive dictionary in almost anything... no? what are you using?

elements.text: JSON becomes recursive dictionary in almost anything... no? what are you using?

text: but anyway, the point is that if you build a binary schema on file (say, i always write this field then followed by the length of the array with 8 bits, etc...) you will probably get something faster today, but tomorrow if you need to change the schema, you may get a hard time.. and in the end you reinvent the wheel of stuff like protobufs or parquet

elements.text: but anyway, the point is that if you build a binary schema on file (say, i always write this field then followed by the length of the array with 8 bits, etc...) you will probably get something faster today, but tomorrow if you need to change the schema, you may get a hard time.. and in the end you reinvent the wheel of stuff like protobufs or parquet

text: Yeah I know what you mean. Mods can be tricky. I'm thinking of basic stuff though. Let's take a stupid example - backtesting a lay the field strategy inplay. You are parsing JSON time and time again but ultimately you are only interested in a handful of coefficients calculated from that entire data file. Its a poor example probably. OBviously it would only work for a very limited and targeted type of backtest/simulation - I was just wondering if anyone had tried this kind of thing.

elements.text: Yeah I know what you mean. Mods can be tricky. I'm thinking of basic stuff though. Let's take a stupid example - backtesting a lay the field strategy inplay. You are parsing JSON time and time again but ultimately you are only interested in a handful of coefficients calculated from that entire data file. Its a poor example probably. OBviously it would only work for a very limited and targeted type of backtest/simulation - I was just wondering if anyone had tried this kind of thing.

text:
In python it’s the creation of objects that takes the large majority of time as shown by the Rust library, reading json isn’t worth the optimisation. Have you profiled your code? 

I use s3 for storing the data but have a local cache (~100gb) to remove the network latency

text: I've been having similar thoughts recently <@UUE6E1LA1>. Although I am mainly thinking around the inefficiency of having to build the cache from the deltas over and over again. Storage costs aside, would be better to store each individual market book. My idea was to try sticking it in a tabular format (indexed by publish time, selection ID, handicap, side and depth) and saving as parquet format. <@ULDAVFDRP> had some interesting things to say about the storage and random access look up of market books but I've given up hope of hearing from him again

elements.text: I've been having similar thoughts recently

. Although I am mainly thinking around the inefficiency of having to build the cache from the deltas over and over again. Storage costs aside, would be better to store each individual market book. My idea was to try sticking it in a tabular format (indexed by publish time, selection ID, handicap, side and depth) and saving as parquet format.
had some interesting things to say about the storage and random access look up of market books but I've given up hope of hearing from him again

text: I don't (for sure) at the moment <@U4H19D1D2> I probably should have written a large proportion of the *code* is parsing JSON/recreating market update by update. What motivated this vein of thought was when doing anything analytical with GPS data I need to read in 2 files - GPS and market. That got me thinking about a new format containing all data I need. Looking at the compact nature of the GPS feed, it was screaming out for a binary approach (which is probably how it comes off the sensor hardware anyway). Now, say for example, that I am only interested nonvirtual market book prices and volumes as they stand at the time of a GPS update it would mean I can discard those wasted frames that I am calculating.

text: Yes <@UBS7QANF3> this is how I feel. I'd much rather be reading in a preprocessed time series of price matrices than recreating off the deltas.

text: About 7 years ago I went to <http://freelancer.com|freelancer.com> and within a couple of days I got talking to someone who ended up employing me on a really fun and interesting two year project (C++ on Android devices). Then about three years ago I found myself unemployed and went back to freelancer confidently expecting the same kind of thing to happen - but this time zilch, zip, nada. I applied for dozens of projects over many weeks and got nothing at all. Either the site has somehow gotten worse or I was just incredibly lucky first time round. BTW, to this day I have no idea how the bidding system really works - the bids for most projects seem ridiculously tiny - it's hard to imagine that they are the actual prices people end up paying.

Then about three years ago I found myself unemployed and went back to freelancer confidently expecting the same kind of thing to happen - but this time zilch, zip, nada. I applied for dozens of projects over many weeks and got nothing at all. Either the site has somehow gotten worse or I was just incredibly lucky first time round. BTW, to this day I have no idea how the bidding system really works - the bids for most projects seem ridiculously tiny - it's hard to imagine that they are the actual prices people end up paying.

text: I've no idea what you're all taking about and maybe it's all amazing, but everything of mine is in good old SQL. Not cool not sexy but does the job.   I don't use backtesting as a sledgehammer anyway, just a few well designed tests and I've got more than enough to look at and idle capacity while I'm doing it. More haste less speed :wink:
